results.title: Vegetable Growing at Home
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film is a government-produced educational film designed to encourage viewers to grow their own vegetables at home during the Second World War. Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, the film features a suburban couple who receive a brochure in the mail called ‘Wartime Vegetable Growing at Home’. The educational intent of the film is interspersed with comic scenes predicated on the (now outdated) gender roles of the time as the domestic housewife, Mary, sabotages her husband’s plans to play golf and convinces him to start a vegetable garden. With the assistance of the girl next door, a student at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the hapless husband begins transforming his patch of grass and stops sulking. Moving to an instructional section filmed at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the film’s narrator explains how to dig a patch, turn over and rake the soil, and plant seeds, with the process performed by another expert female gardener (despite clearly being a skilled professional, the narrator mocks her for being a woman). The gardener then demonstrates how to thin out young plants, cultivate the soil and deal with pests, with occasional interludes back to the comic scenes of the domestic couple. Finally, the film shows the rewards of growing your own vegetables, with a bountiful harvest from the garden.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: My university challenge
results.creator_credit: Ray Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ray Martin and his girlfriend enrolled in a university course in Thailand to become qualified English teachers. It was here that Martin set himself a challenge that not many people had been successful at achieving.

results.title: Unwise and foolish creations of fancy
results.creator_credit: Sally McCutcheon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Sally McCutcheon tells her story, threaded together by her two life-long passions, dancing and beading. Through determination, discipline and the support of her family, McCutcheon has managed to excel at both at different stages of her life.

results.title: How should we remember Stuart?
results.creator_credit: Kath Ensor, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Speaking for her grandmother, Elizabeth, Kath Ensor remembers her grandfather, Stuart. Encompassing his time serving in the RAAF during World War II, his love for his family and his positive attitude, despite experiencing ill health.

results.title: Proceed to the blue desk please
results.creator_credit: Simone West, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Simone West juxtaposes the urgency of processing child patients that are suffering from burns with the sense of urgency that assail the loved ones that want everything to be ok.

results.title: 'Remembrance of things past'...a watercolour memoir for Richard
results.brief_description: When Judith recalls Richard’s legacy, she sees it through his watercolour paintings that stand as a aesthetic record to his life, from his childhood to his adult academic pursuits.
